title-group.article-title: Clinical Course of ICU Patients With Severe Pandemic 2009 Influenza A (H1N1) Pneumonia
title-group.subtitle: Single Center Experience With Proning and Pressure Release Ventilation

article-meta.aff: 1Departments of Medicine and Respiratory Care, Utah Valley Regional Medical Center, Provo, UT, USA

author-notes.corresp: Krishna M. Sundar, University of Utah, Intermountain Utah Valley Pulmonary Clinic, 1055N, 300W, Suite 500, Provo, UT 84604, USA. Email: Krishna.sundar@imail.org

abstract.p: Received June 10, 2010, and in revised form July 26, 2010. Accepted for publication August 12, 2010. Background: A number of different modalities have been employed in addition to conventional ventilation to improve oxygenation in patients with severe 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) pneumonia. Outcomes with ventilatory and rescue therapies for H1N1 influenza-related acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) have been varied.1–6 A single intensive care unit (ICU) experience with management of laboratory-confirmed 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) ARDS with a combination of proning and airway pressure release ventilation (APRV) is described. Methods: A retrospective review of medical records of ICU patients seen at Utah Valley Regional Medical Center during the first and second waves of the H1N1 influenza pandemic was done. Results: Fourteen ICU patients were managed with invasive ventilation for 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1)-related ARDS. Hypoxemia refractory to conventional ventilation was noted in 11 of 14 patients despite application of APRV. Following proning in patients on APRV, improvement of hypoxemia and hemodynamic status was achieved. Only 2 of 11 patients on APRV and proning required continuous dialysis. Mortality in intubated patients receiving a combination of proning and APRV was 27.3% (3/11) with 2 of these dying during the first wave of the H1N1 influenza pandemic. In all, 3 of 11 patients on proning and APRV underwent tracheostomy, with 2 of these undergoing tube thoracostomy. ARDSnet fluid-conservative protocol was safely tolerated in 8 of 11 of the intubated patients following initiation of proning and APRV. Conclusions: Proning in combination with APRV provides improvement of hypoxemia with limitation of end-organ dysfunction and thereby facilitates recovery from severe 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe hypoxemia can ensue in patients with H1N1 influenza pnuemonia.1–4 A number of reports have described difficulty with managing hypoxemia in severe H1N1 influenza pneumonia despite using high levels of positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) with conventional volume-cycled and pressure-cycled ventilatory modes.2–4 This has triggered the use of additional therapies like prone ventilation, high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) to improve oxygenation in these intubated patients.2–4 The need for these additional strategies for improving hypoxemia in intubated H1N1 patients has led to a call for management of these patients in centers that have expertise with additional therapies for improving hypoxemia.5

The choice of additional therapy to improve oxygenation is based on center availability and expertise in the particular modality used. Our center has used airway pressure release ventilation (APRV—Draeger Evita XL, Lubeck, Germany) and automated rotational proning (KCI Rotoprone bed, KCI USA, San Antonio, Texas) for the management of severe cases of ARDS for the last 3 years. We report our experience with 21 intensive care unit (ICU) patients with confirmed pandemic H1N1 influenza pneumonia.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A retrospective review of the ICU course of patients encountered during the first and second waves of the H1N1 influenza pandemic (June-August 2010 and September-November 2010, respectively) at the Utah Valley Regional Medical Center, Provo, Utah was done (Graph 1 ). During these 2 waves of the H1N1 pandemic, 57 patients were hospitalized of which 21 patients were admitted to the ICU (Graph 1). Patient records were reviewed for ventilator data, ICU length of stay and duration of ventilation, use of antibiotics and steroids, need for dialysis, and outcomes. Consent from Intermountain Institutional Review Board was obtained for waiver of patient consent for retrospective analysis of patient data.

caption.p: Numbers of hospitalized patients and intensive care unit (ICU) patients with H1N1 influenza infection encountered at the Utah Valley Regional Medical Center, Provo, Utah.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The overall experience with 2009 pandemic influenza (H1N1) pneumonia requiring ICU care at our institution is detailed in Table 1 . Diagnosis of H1N1 infection was made from H1N1 influenza real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) done on either nasal secretions or bronchoalveolar lavage (19/21), or culture of respiratory secretions (2/21). A total of 21 patients were managed in the ICU during the first and second waves of the H1N1 novel influenza pandemic. Of 21 patients, 14 had severe H1N1 influenza pneumonia that required mechanical ventilation for more than 48 hours. Apart from moderate to morbid obesity that has been reported as a common association in patients with H1N1 influenza ARDS,2,3,6 only few other comorbidities or associations were noted in the group treated with mechanical ventilation (mood disorders 8/14, smoking 4/14, immunosuppression 2/14). Blood-tinged frothy secretions simulating cardiogenic pulmonary edema were noted in all patients in the immediate postintubation period. All patients were treated with oseltamivir orally 150 mg/day for 5 days after admission. All patients were on antibiotics empirically with the majority being on ceftriaxone and azithromycin. Of 21 patients, 3 had complicating pneumococcal infection with 1 of these having bacteremia and septic shock. Stress dose steroids were given to 6 of 14 of the intubated patients (hydrocortisone 400 mg/day intravenously) during the first few days of ICU stay for circulatory shock. 2/14 of the intubated patients were given high-dose steroids (methylprednisolone 180-240mg/day) in the first week of ICU stay. One additional intubated patient received high-dose steroids from day 9 of the ICU stay.

caption.p: Characteristics of Intensive Care Unit (ICU) Patients With H1N1 Influenza Pneumonia Requiring Mechanical and Noninvasive Ventilator Support

fn.p: Abbreviations: APRV, airway pressure release ventilation; Paw, inflating airway pressures Phigh.

sec.p: Improvement of hypoxemia was noted in the proned patients within a few hours of the proning maneuver (Table 3). None of the patients required paralytics. Of the 11 proned patients, 2 necessitated continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT), 1 in the first week from H1N1 ARDS and the second for multiorgan failure due to nosocomial pneumonia following recovery from H1N1 ARDS. Out of 5 transthoracic echocardiograms done in the first week in patients on proning and APRV, 2 showed evidence of mild right atrial enlargement and increased tricuspid regurgitant velocities and 1 showed severe right atrial dilatation and left ventricular ejection fraction of 30%. Improvement in hemodynamic status with maintenance of optimal urine output was observed following initiation of proning in all but 1 patient who went on to develop renal failure necessitating CRRT. Improvements in hemodynamic status allowed for early reductions (within 1-3 days) in doses of pressors and institution of the ARDSnet conservative fluid protocol.9

Overall mortality in patients treated in the ICU was 19% and in patients proned and on APRV was 27.3% (4/11 patients; Tables 1 and 2). All these deaths occurred in intubated patients. Causes of death included severe refractory hypoxemia and shock in a morbidly obese patient who could not be proned, anoxic encephalopathy, pneumococcal sepsis in a patient with developmental delay and immune deficiency, and withdrawal of care in a patient with Down’s syndrome and interstitial lung disease after 23 days of ICU stay. In 10 of the 14 intubated patients that survived, overall duration of ventilatory support was 19.2 days and duration of hospital stay was 24.8 days. Of the 10 of 14 intubated patients that survived, 5 patients were discharged home and 5 required acute rehabilitation or skilled nursing post-discharge. Tube thoracostomy was required in 15.4% of intubated patients for pulmonary barotrauma and tracheostomy was done in 31% patients requiring ventilatory care more than 10 days.

Out of the total of 21 patients treated in the ICU for 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) pneumonia, 7 were treated predominantly with bilevel positive airway ventilation (BiPAP; 2 of 7 in this group required invasive ventilation for less than 48 hours). Five of seven patients on noninvasive ventilation (NIV) were given high-dose steroids for treating accompanying chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD) exacerbation. The mean age of patients treated predominantly with noninvasive ventilation was significantly greater than those requiring invasive ventilation (39 years vs 55.7 years [P = .028]). Majority of the patients treated predominantly with BiPAP had either chronic cardiopulmonary ailments like COPD (6/7) or congestive heart failure (2/7). There was no significant difference in the BMI of patients undergoing noninvasive vs invasive ventilation (P = .62; Table 1). Duration of BiPAP therapy ranged from 18 hours to 8 days.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Deaths from H1N1 influenza have been attributed to severe ARDS leading to refractory hypoxemia, shock, and multiorgan failure.2–4,6,10,11 Acute respiratory distress syndrome results from direct pulmonary involvement from severe influenza infection and accompanying bacterial infection is noted in >25% of patients undergoing autopsy.11,12 The occurrence of severe hypoxemia in ARDS resulting from H1N1 influenza pneumonia has led to the use of additional nonconventional therapies like proning and ECMO. Large randomized studies on ARDS patients with multiple differing etiologies for ARDS have not shown any mortality benefit with either proning or ECMO.13,14 Despite this, the paramount need for correcting hypoxemia in these critically ill patients from H1N1 ARDS has led to the adoption of these strategies in a number of tertiary centers. Reports on larger trials from Canada and Australia-New Zealand (ANZ-ECMO) indicate a high frequency of additional therapies for the management of severe ARDS related to 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) pneumonia.3,4 In the 168 critically ill H1N1 patients reported from Canada, additional interventions included neuromuscular paralysis (28%), HFOV (11.9%), inhaled nitric oxide (13.7%), prone ventilation (3%), and ECMO (4.2%).3

We describe a single-center experience with proning and APRV for the management of ARDS from H1N1 influenza. Airway pressure release ventilation (APRV) is a time-triggered, pressure-cycled mode of ventilation that allows for spontaneous breathing during the whole phase of the respiratory cycle.15 Airway pressure release ventilation has been widely used in patients with ARDS and has been shown to decrease the need for paralysis and sedation as compared to other modes of ventilation.16,17 In addition to promoting alveolar recruitment and increasing cardiac performance, it has been purported to be a less injurious ventilatory strategy in ARDS in general.18

Proning has been extensively used for improving hypoxemia in patients with ARDS .13,19 Multiple mechanisms interact to bring about the oxygenation improvement resulting from proning.19 Proning has been shown to unload the right ventricle and improve hemodynamics in patients with severe ARDS.20 Despite the consistent lack of mortality benefit in ARDS,13 multiple reports continue to favor a beneficial role of prone positioning in ARDS patients with most severe hypoxemia.21,22 Combinations of different additional modalities have been described in the literature to improve oxygenation in patients with severe ARDS.23–25 The study by Varpula et al compared effects of 2 episodes of proning on oxygenation in patients with acute lung injury that were randomized to APRV or synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation.23 Patients that were proned after being on APRV had better oxygenation following 2 episodes of proning.23 The authors concluded that APRV after 24 hours appeared to enhance improvements in oxygenation in response to proning.23

In our experience, proning of patients with H1N1 influenza-related ARDS led to improvements in oxygenation in all of the patients treated in our ICU (Table 3). Airway pressure release ventilation alone was not successful in reversing the hypoxemia and therefore proning was instituted in the majority of intubated patients with mean time to proning reducing with the succeeding wave of pandemic. Proning also appeared to improve the hemodynamic status and urinary output within 24 to 48 hours allowing early institution of the ARDSnet conservative protocol for fluid management. Unlike other reports on intubated patients with 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) pneumonia, where a significant need for dialysis was reported from shock and multiorgan failure,2–4,6,10 only 1 patient on proning and APRV required CRRT secondary to multiorgan failure from H1N1 influenza-related ARDS. The “shock” component in patients with severe H1N1 ARDS may therefore occur from application of high positive thoracic pressures and severe hypoxemia rather than from circulatory collapse from systemic inflammatory response. With improvement in oxygenation and hemodynamic parameters following proning, there was improvement in end-organ function as assessed by urinary output and renal function.

The PaO2 to FiO2 ratios (P/F ratio) in our study was comparable to the ANZ-ECMO study (n = 68; mean P/F ratio 56 (range 48-63)).4 Mortality in the ANZ-ECMO population was 20.5% (14/68) compared to the mortality of 28.6% (4/14) in intubated H1N1 patients in our study. Our overall mortality was comparable to an ICU cohort of H1N1 influenza patients managed in an adjoining county in Utah where no “rescue therapies” for managing the severe hypoxemia were used.6 Although mortality in our ICU patients (19%) was comparable to the mortality of 17% in the cohort of 47 ICU patients in Miller et al’s study, the organ failure rate was much lower (7% in our study compared to 13% CRRT requirement in Miller et al’s study). Additionally, none of our patients were paralyzed as compared to 47% of patients requiring paralysis in Miller et al’s study.6

As compared to ECMO that has been used in patients with H1N1 influenza-related ARDS,2–4,26 proning can be undertaken without need for additional skilled personnel required for managing ECMO especially when automated rotational proning with kinetic therapy is used.27 Automated rotational proning has been recently advocated for patients with severe oxygenation defects from ARDS.27 Even though P/F ratios in our study were comparable to Bajwa et al’s study using similar rotational proning therapy, improvements in P/F ratios following initiation of proning were not as dramatic.27 Proning-related complications in our study, facial sores or ulcers were few and comparable to complications encountered in the Prone-Supine study II.13

A number of infectious and bleeding complications have been reported with ECMO for H1N1 influenza pneumonia.4 A need for addition of ECMO to patients who had failed proning maneuvers has been reported,3,4 but no additional therapy beyond proning and APRV was required to improve oxygenation in our patients. Although there are case reports of use of HFOV in H1N1 and H5N1 influenza pneumonia,28,29 no larger series are available on outcomes with the use of HFOV in intubated patients with H1N1 influenza pneumonia. One prior study on ARDS showed that prone positioning improved oxygenation and indices of lung inflammation as compared to supine-HFOV.30 Whether this independently contributes to more favorable outcomes from proning in H1N1 influenza-related ARDS is unknown.

In our study, 7 patients were managed predominantly with NIV in the ICU. Reports of benefit with NIV in pandemic 2009 H1N1 pnuemonia-related ARDS have been varied.31,32 Benefit from NIV was felt most in patients with accompanying chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and congestive heart failure in our study. Despite limited availability of negative pressure isolation rooms and the risk of air-borne transmission,31 a number of patients in our ICU were managed with NIV given the improvement in their respiratory status with NIV alone. Due barrier precautions, usage of full-face masks, avoidance of heated humidifier, disposal of filters, masks etc, and complete decontamination of NIV-machines was done to minimize the spread of air-borne transmission.33

The 2009 pandemic stretched ICU resources across the world with a need for critical care beds, ventilators, necessary staffing, and pharmacy supplies.34 In centers employing rescue therapies like ECMO and proning, availability of these rescue therapies was stretched thin due to their limited availability from their infrequent use in nonepidemic times. A critical need for automated proning beds was noted at our center given the average duration of proning of 4.6 days in our study with 2 patients being proned for 8 or more days. The time to initiation to proning was significantly earlier for ICU patients with 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) ARDS during the second wave as compared to the first wave. Possible reasons for earlier proning times during the second wave was felt to be changing clinician attitudes toward proning based on accumulated experience from first wave and more awareness about the severity of oxygenation defect in intubated patients with pandemic 2009 influenza (H1N1) pneumonia. Earlier proning for longer periods of time was shown to be beneficial in severe ARDS patients (PaO2:FiO2 ratio ≤88 mm Hg) as shown in study by Mancebo et al on patients with ARDS from differing etiologies35 although the larger Prone-Supine II study group did not show similar benefits.13 Prolonged prone ventilation was shown to be safe in patients manually proned for a mean of 17 hours per day for up to 10 days35 and in patients proned using rotational proning bed for more than 6 days.27 Significant usage of continuous sedation for proned patients was noted in our study. The need to plan for shortages of sedative agents has been recommended following the first wave of the novel influenza pandemic.36

A number of challenges have been identified during the management of patients with the 2009 pandemic influenza (H1N1) pneumonia-related ARDS31,34,37 and the lessons learnt during this pandemic can be used for improving ICU care of similar patients during future influenza epidemics. Severe hypoxemia can ensue in patients with 2009 pandemic influenza (H1N1)-related ARDS that can worsen following initiation of invasive mechanical ventilation.2–6,10,28,31,34 Therefore, the need for additional therapies beyond conventional ventilation to improve hypoxemia should be anticipated. Use of additional strategies to maintain oxygenation may be crucial to favorable outcomes of these patients.2–4 While these recommendations may be applicable to all patients with ARDS, the need to employ additional strategies early on may be critical to survival and minimization of end-organ dysfunction in patients with severe H1N1 influenza pneumonia. Even though our study was limited because of a retrospective design and a small number of patients, proning in combination with APRV appeared to improve the severe hypoxemia and thereby the outcomes of intubated ICU patients with pandemic influenza (H1N1) pneumonitits. The combination of proning and APRV should be considered for improving outcomes of ventilated patients with severe influenza-related pneumonia and ARDS.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: The authors thank Dr Russell Miller III, Division of Pulmonary & Critical Care Medicine, Intermountain Medical Center, Murray, Utah, for his review and expert comments on the manuscript.

The author(s) received no financial support for the research and/or authorship of this article.
